newsitem.title: USA: US spot resid prices pressured by growing supply.
newsitem.headline: US spot resid prices pressured by growing supply.

text.p: U.S. spot residual fuel oil prices ended flat to lower Tuesday, pressured by growing supply and little spot demand in the Gulf and East Coast.
"There isn't really any demand," said one cash resid trader, noting the continued slump in buying interest from most Northeast electric utilities.
An Illinois utility reportedly issued today a tender for over 100,000 barrels of 0.7 percent sulphur resid material for early April delivery.
"It shouldn't put much pressure on prices," said one Gulf fuel oil dealer, referring to the tender's small volume.
The dealer said there is ample supply from Caribbean and South America to meet any incremental fuel oil demand.
Separately, barge traffic on the Mississippi River continued to be restricted amid efforts to clean up a petrochemical spill after a barge carrying the toxic material capsized March 17.

USG three percent sulphur grade tightened to $13.75-14.00 a barrel from Monday's $13.75-14.2. USG three percent paper for April softened to $13.20-40 from $13.25-50 yesterday. One percent physical was still thinly discussed at $14.75-15.00.
In the New York harbor, the one percent physical quote narrowed to $15.50-75 from Monday's $15.50-16.00 as offers were heard as low as $15.50.
One percent NYH paper for balance of April was assessed at $15.15-15.30, slightly lower than $15.20-35 Monday.
NYH HSFO materials were thinly discussed with three percent remaining at $13.50-75.
NYMEX May crude futures extended yesterday's decline, settling down 13 cents at $20.28 a barrel.

Swing gas deliveries at New York City gate for Wednesday were quoted at $2.15-2.20 per million British thermal units (mmBtu) or $13.67 a barrel equivalent after a winter-like storm pushed across the Northeast yesterday.
Gas prices for April 2 delivery were lower than Monday's $2.40/mmBtu or $15.12/bbl equivalent on forecasts of more spring-like temperatures returning to the Northeast.
Natgas at Henry Hub, the NYMEX delivery point, rose to $1.94/mmBtu or $12.22/bbl equivalent from Monday's $1.84/mmBtu or $11.59/bbl equivalent.
